reviews.review_msg: Dr. Davidson doesn't have a focus in class. Class is just discussion about somewhat related topic. He did not cover any research on adolescent development. The tests consist of only essay questions which are very philosophical in nature. I do not recommend.

I have never felt so inspired by a professor. He is funny, engaging, outspoken, genuine, and his stories will break your heart. It is easy to see how he is such an awesome therapist - he sees the best in everyone. Many students felt like crying on the last day. He is the opposite of condescending. Beware, his tests are not easy.
Exams are essays and short answers which is lots of writing and hard to get marks. The outline of paper is broad and difficult to know what the prof wants.

Such a wasted opportunity,I was excited for the next instalment of the developmental process&instead was subjected to his verbal vomit, unclear, nonchalant teaching style&outrageous marking scheme. Don't tell us to be creative with the course material then make a structured rubric for marking. Probs a great therapist but I want a prof not a BFF.
LIKES: encourages critical thinking, engaging, smart. DISLIKES: goes off tangent, his jokes/laid back style distracts from his teaching so it's hard to take him srsly sometimes. hard marking scheme!

He's kinda like the equivalent of the 'diary of a wimpy kid' books for preteens. Like they're funny and entraining but you really don't learn anything. Like a way to get kids interesting in reading. But if you already like reading it really doesn't do much for you.
dope teacher. enjoyed going to class and he is a total bro, recommend taking whatever class he teaches. really gets you thinking about stuff. thanks for a great year man

A great professor who strives to move past the memorization/regurgitation method of doing exams. Attending lectures is half the battle to passing the course. Very approachable and brings real life applications forward in explaining the materials. If you don't mind using your brain to think this is a good instructor to take classes with.

Professor is fun and humorous, but there were major discrepancies between what was taught and what was expected in the midterm. 155 people out of 237 received 62% or less on the multiple choice. Also, people are encouraged to voice concerns or opinions but then are allowed to be attacked or invalidated by other classmates.

Martin is great ! He is very approachable and relatable. He sends very interesting/informative emails frequently to his students. In class he gets across the most important points of the course and adds in his own personal view on things, which were mostly always outside the box. I would recommend going to lectures but not getting the text.

Awesome professor! He's clearly into his lecture and puts a genuine effort into trying to make people feel welcomed. His examples used in-class helped a great deal with remembering concepts taught in class. He even took the time to explain to me the rules of chess after I blurted out I didn't know how the game worked...oh yeah he played chess.

Martin is awesome. Super funny and helpful. if its not on the lecture slides, it wont be on the exams. so no need to read the texbook. still, study hard and you'll get a good grade. exams are M/C with short answer questions given to you ahead of time. Take his class if you can! TAs mark you paper, so talk to them before hand.
He is the funniest prof i have ever had! very comfortable with student, does not take him self seriously... He is perfect. midterm and final were fair overall.

Best prof Ive had at sfu. Hilarious yet informative. Random swear words throughout lecture were endearing. Attending lectures were always a treat. His exams are pretty fair as well. He's all about the human experience rather than over intellectualizing. Obviously cares about his clients and his students.
Martin is the most laid back prof I've ever had. I really enjoyed his teaching style. His exams and assignments were fair. His use of humor made the course fun. I would recommend taking his class.
such a nice professor and make the class so interesting!!!!

Martin is a wonderful prof! His lectures were recorded, but attending them were definitely fun. He encouraged questions and class discussions and made an effort to make them engaging and interesting. Exams were MC + written. 4 Essay topics were given before the exam, and 2 of which will be chosen. One of my most enjoyable courses at SFU

I don't know why people are complaining. He is an AWESOME prof, who pretty much tells you what's gonna be on the midterm and final. If you go to class, and study the lecture notes, you'll do great. He's also really nice, funny, and willing to offer help if you need it. One of my favorite profs, and favorite classes of my psychology undergrad at SFU
i do not understand what he is talking about

if i were you, run away from this prof. i agree that's y professor should have a phd before they teach. he talks very  fast, n difficult to understand. this is an advice to follow if you want to maintain your gpa.
Pretty hard class, all moral/cognitive development, fast talker, but very passionate about the subject matter. Take his class if you like a challenge (some interesting concepts too)

Travis's lectures are great! If you put enough time and effort in your study, you will be satisfied with your results.  It is an advangate for us that he gives us the exam questions prior to the exam.  If you're not a slacker, I gurantee that you will not regret taking his course. Besides, the material he covers is very interesting!

Obviously enthusiastic about his topic. Maybe a little too enthusiastic...he really needs to cut down on caffeine and energy drinks. His pacing really tired me out! The course felt a bit repetitive, covering similar concepts over and over, but it was interesting.

RUN AWAY!!!  Travis is a TERRIBLE prof!  He talks waaay to fast, and rambles so much you never know what he is talking about.  His notes are useless (they usually lack nouns and subjects, so you don't know what topic he is talking about).  Sure, the study giudes are good, but they are very hard, and have too many questions to memorize for the test.
No Comments
Boring as heck....useless..is more like a history class then a psyc class

What a waste of time....his teaching is NOT about psyc..nothing about adolesence development.  He should teach phil. instead.  His exam were LONG and Hard! Even if he gives it ahead of time...you can't find the answers in the text or his notes.  Avoid if u can.  I did okay in that class...but is the worst class ever!

At first i thought this class was going to be extremely difficult. i was even thinking about dropping it. His midterms are easy... given that he gives the questions before... he is very organized and cute!  Travis is so smart yet so young. I look up to him. Take this course with travis!

I thought he was okay. I thought that since it was an adolescent class that he would have talked about adolescents rather than phil...but I suppose he was just talking about what he found interesting. Also the TA in the class were AWFUL!

I took this course because I thought it was a psyc course but all he talked about for the whole semester was philosophical stuff that was soooo boring. His exams are hard eventhough he gives practice questions before hand. They are long and him and his TA's are terrible markers. He never took the effort to make sure his lectures are being recorded

He's only a PhD candidate, but Travis is the smartest prof to have ever graced SFU. He's not only passionate about the subject, he's one of the most animated and interesting speakers I've ever known. Exam questions are given before actual exam, so as long as you put effort into it, it's not hard to ace. Plus, he's SO CUTE in his sweater vests.
DO NOT EVER TAKE HIS CLASS. He's so arrogant and pompous. He doesn't use presentations so you basically spend 3 hours listening to him rant about something irrelevant.

It helps when you ask questions in class and get to know him. He shares a lot of stories from his clinical work and brings relevance to what we learn in class. Lectures are recorded, which is great as I had 830am class. Downside is he does not use powerpoint or give lecture notes, so just listen and take notes. Exams are 85% based on the textbook!
No point going to lecture, just read the text, his lectures are all over the place. Tests are hard as you have to teach yourself. Just read the books. Lectures are recorded

AVOID this class! Complete waste of time and extremely hard to get a good mark with tons of hardwork. 12 chp cumulative final, provides no notes, no hints, no guidelines of what to focus on. Waste of time and money!! He needs to retire seriously!!!

Attendance is unnecessary- no pwr points, no overhead notes, no written notes. His stories about his life/experience are interesting but don't help for exams. Study the textbook & do the online practice tests (link at the end of each chapter). Most of the MC were on the exam. Short answer expects too much, & the TA's mark HARD!

Exams based almost entirely from text. Occasional written question from lecture, but it's nearly impossible to predict the questions as just about any small detail from the book is fair game. His wealth of clinical experience makes some lectures interesting but I wouldn't recommend this course unless you enjoy working extra hard for a so-so mark.

Not a good professor.  He seems to care more about his other profession (Lawyer) more than teaching a class.  I feel my $ was wasted and I was extremely interested in this class.  I studied hard and went to every class but his exams are ridiculously tricky (on purpose).  You will enjoy this class if you like nothing more than the bare minimum.

Robert is a professor who seems to not really care about his students. He insists on being the last professor at SFU to lecture without slides or PowerPoints. As a result he has little structure and goes on many tangents, so attendance is not overly necessary. Midterms were relatively tough as he designs questions to trick you which I find silly.

I found this class interesting, except I know a lot of people were upset with their Midterm grade the second round around. As for the final, there was two parts, which students complained was "extremely difficult". Pay attention to every detail, and the studies that were ran. He will ask for ridiculous minor details you wouldn't think would be on i

He's alright if you like professors who are very talkative. No structure whatsoever though, and no PPT. I'll admit he is interesting, but the things he talks about aren't really related to what you're tested on. My advice: read the textbook THOROUGHLY and even if you skip lectures, you'll get a mark that's at least a B+.

No need to attend class, no papers, only two midterms and then cumulative exam. Exams are mainly from textbook, so study it well! Multiple choice is pretty straightforward, short answers are mainly definitions. Great class :)

I really enjoyed Dr Ley's lectures, he talks around the subject & uses real world/clinical examples. He also comes across as a really nice/approachable guy. As far as the class goes, tests are 99% from the text, which he doesn't talk about, and it's like any DEV class in that you have to be able to memorize tons of theories by tons of people.
Funniest prof I've ever had and a very nice person to. Super approachable and personable. Most enjoyable class to attend.

A seasoned prof that is keen to give students lots of info about his field. Uses real examples from his patients in class to make things more concrete. WARNING: Class attendance is more for "interest" than exam preparation. If you want to do well on the tests, just read the book! But the prof is interesting and friendly. A keeper!
while lectures are interesting, they are certainly short on content. doesnt seem to put a lot of effort into preparing for lectures.  seems like a nice guy and easy exams though.

The BEST Psychology professor SFU has! I recommand taking 355 and 356 with Ley. His lectures are really funny and he doesn't use boring overheads or powerpoint. The short answers on the midterm and final exam were a bit tricky. Term paper was exactly what you would do for 201 but now you focus on adolescences.

Best prof i've ever had. Lectures are entertaining, interesting, and don't bore with powerp. presentations where one reads off the screen. Know definitions and text readings for tests which are extremely fair. Go to class, he's hilarious and treats students fairly. Love this guy!
Good prof, interesting stories, good text, tutorials are boring.

you don't have to go to class; if you do ley will speak very slowly and take up a lot of your time explaining 1st year concepts. the textbook is clear enough, but expresses some very biased opinions without seeming to recognize it, and is very tedious to read. this class was not nearly as interesting as it could have been. good if you like easy.

very interesting lectures. tells lots of interesting anecdotes. the tests are based on the textbook though so the only reason to go to class is to listen to his interesting stories, and to help you out on the essay and short answer questions.

he has a sense of humour and he provides good anecdotes. exams are tough cuz he asks some detailed m/c questions so definitely read the text! it was good that he allowed choices in the short answer and essay part of the exam though. the tutorials weren't that helpful.
The funniest prof @ SFU. His anecdotes are the reason why I attended lecture.  His midterm is very long and mostly focused on the text, not his lecture. Take his course if you have the chance!!
Nice guy, interesting material/lectures.  Exams are kinda tough though, so watch out
he's a freudian.  take that as you will...
Made topic interesting. I like how he brings in personal stories and tries to be funny.
Horrible class - you could follow along in the text.  Bad presenter, boring term project.
No Comments
Makes topic interesting. I had a good T.A.
No Comments

I've had Sherri multiple times and she is an amazing prof! Her exams are fair and tests almost exclusively on lecture content (there is usually a bonus question about something that was discussed in class). She is super funny and the stories/personal examples she tells in class are super interesting. All exam based which I loved!

Sherrie is very approachable and I appreciate how much she likes to have class discussions. But, she often rambles and it is difficult to know what she will/won't test on. She also loves to ask questions specifically about class discussions and we had multiple technical issues, so students who could not attend lecture were at an unfair disadvantage
If you forget one of the concepts during an exam you may lose over 20%.

She's funny but often rambles on about her personal experiences. She grades out of 4 exams only and they're all essay-style questions which I think is quite unfair given that she doesn't emphasize what would be tested, resulting in students studying the wrong thing. She made some exams more difficult because the department would lower grades.

Pros= funny, decent lecturer. Cons= all short answer difficult exams, no effort to fix lecture recording issues, worries about the grades being too high and does not take into account how students may be hardworking and deserving of grades, doesn't curve grades, random things are tested example how many students put their hands up for a question.

It really feels like she wants you to fail the course because the exams are extremely difficult and unfair. If you happen to remember the few things she wants to test you for then you are lucky, otherwise how well you learn in general isn't relevant.

Her lectures are okay, but her exams are difficult as they consist entirely of short answer questions. Concerned that the grades were too high last semester she has stated this many times that the exams will be difficult. She will alter the exams when students do well and make it more difficult. It feels like she does not want students to succeed.
Terrible person

Her classes are not bad; sometimes, they get boring. However, her exam questions are quite weird, and they don't really test your knowledge. You need to be a master of writing Bullsh** to get a good grade. Many questions can be answered with just one sentence, yet you're expected to write a whole page. Avoiding her class if possible.

Absolutely awful. Rambled on about unrelated things. Used 10 slides per 3 hour lecture, readings were largely unrelated. Same concepts as presented in PSYC 250. Absolute waste of time. Test questions were worded weirdly, even the TA thought they were poorly done. Doesn't publish lectures online, but tests exclusively on those conversations. AVOID.

My experience with Sherrie via remote class was disappointing and frustrating. Lectures were not structured/were rambly, tests were disorganized & quite challenging due to abstract questions. Sherrie did not seem to be prepared (often) nor did she seem to have much passion/care toward the class. The course strayed from adolescent development often

The proff is very disorganized. I did not find myself learning anything important about adolescent development. Even though she told us to get a textbook, exams were mostly on lecture. However even the lecture stuff was disorganized making it very hard to study. When you ask her for clarification she gives attitude and provides very little guidance

Released grades from final exam, same day makes announcement saying won't be taking meetings and to not contact TA's about the grade (no better way to explain why than just saying no exceptions?). Has unclear or vague MC answers, tests on completely random topics from lecture that a random student may say, no way to properly study for the test

She tends to be all over place and disorganized. She likes to show videos and really like discussions. Dont skip class because things you discussed in class WILL be on exams. Exams are highly lecture focused. She wasnt the worst prof Ive met, but also not the best. The project was fun and easy. Exams were fair.
